What We Do in the Shadows (2015) - I've spoken time and time again about my growing distaste in the modern comedy genre. It's gross, un-creative and mostly recycles the same bland jokes, leaving me with the same bad after-taste one would get from eating at a junky fast food chain. So low and behold, what I would consider one of the funniest movies in recent memory somehow gets released in February of 2015... Who knew? Mostly known for their work on "Flight of the Concords", Jermaine Clement and Taika Waititi direct and stars (along with other Concords regulars) in this horror comedy. Shot in a "mockumentary" style ala "This is Spinaltap", the film centers around the hijinx of four room-mates who deal with everyday problems like: who's on dish duty, paying the rent, going out clubbing... Oh, and did I mention they're vampires?... From it's opening moments, the movie introduces its characters and world and wastes no time at all making you laugh. Each character in the film represents a personification of the classic monster from different eras of writing, lending to a culturally diverse set of immortally aged characters which plays into the fun. The movie basically runs on one joke, it just so happens that the one joke is so damn funny it'll have you in stitches until your nose bleeds. My immediate take away from the movie overall was in how likeable this cast is. Make no mistake, these are vicious killers and monsters... But my god are they charming. This is thanks in large part to the devoted cast, who are equally having fun with their respective roles while also bleeding some of their own likeable personalities into the characters. Fake bad accents and all, you completely buy this New Zealand based lot as creatures of the night.With that said, the movie isn't without its detriments. The "mockumentary" shooting style both helps and holds back the film from potentially utilizing some of its gags more effectively. Though I did have fun with the characters interacting with the camera-man, thus breaking the fourth wall... It does suffer a little from the "found footage" symptom of "why are they shooting this now? Why isn't this shot normally?". The visual effects are very simple but get the job done well enough and in most cases actually make the situations more funny. The real issue here lies in the almost transparent plot. As I said, the movie runs on essentially one really well told joke which results in the film losing steam in its third act. The pay-off doesn't feel quite a strong as the set-up which dilutes the experience slightly as a whole.With that said, I do strongly urge everyone to check this movie out whenever it becomes available to you because it's rare that you get a comedy this well executed and dare I say "smart". It re-introduces vampire lore in hilariously situational ways that will have both the horror and comedy fans grinning ear to ear. It's charming, cute while also not pulling any punches with grit and gore. Not since "Shaun of the Dead" has horror and comedy come together this well, it'll have you laughing all the way to your coffin.GRADE: B+

This is all I needed to know: "...creators of the HBO hit series "Flight of the Conchords," co-wrote, co-directed, and co-star in this hilarious send-up in which an endearingly unhip quartet of friends reveal to us or, rather, to the documentary crew that's filming them, the details of their daily-make that nightly-routine."
It's been a long time since I laughed so hard during a movie. Great fun by all the cast.

Some people love documentaries, some people despise them, myself I'm somewhat in the middle, of course the subject has to interest me somewhat for me to even take a look at. Mockumentaries on the other hand I love (when done well) When it comes to mockumentaries, anything and everything goes, there are no real rules, as long as it's somewhat believable, interesting and makes us laugh usually a mockumentary is well received. Give anything some interesting characters and a reality storyline and it's usually enough to make us want to watch. I personally had never heard of "What we do in the shadows" until a friend asked me my thoughts, after watching the trailer I had the film in no time ready to watch.Viago, Deacon, Petyr and Vladislav are four housemates who rent a property in New Zealand, they have lived together for a very long time and know all there is to know about each other, the guys have one thing in common; they are all vampires and each of them is between 100 and 300 years old, never aging from the time they were originally turned. The film follows three of the group as they go about their daily business from their eating habits to their cleaning habits even introducing us at one point to their enemies. Along the way they meet Nick who is turned and decide they need to show him their world and how to survive it on a day to day basis.What we do in the shadows is a laugh a minute, literally. Line after line of jokes, wit and humour never end. Being a mockumentary film the character development is quite strong, you do actually end up feeling sorry and getting involved in each of their lives and the journey they undertake. I personally thought the characters were fantastic, each had their quirks and quips which made them stand out for their own reasons. Starring Jemaine Clement (Eagle Vs Shark, Flight of the Conchords) as Vladislav. Taika Waititi (Eagle vs Shark, Boy) as Viago. Jonathan Brugh (How to meet girls from a distance) as Deacon. Ben Fransham (30 Days of Night, The Ferryman) as Petyr and Cori Gonzalez-Macuer (Eagle vs Shark) as Nick. The guys were brilliant, funny and captivating, never taking themselves too seriously but seriously enough to engage you in their mishaps and adventures.The film is based around a short film made by the same people in 2006, being a mockumentary the camera work is pretty much hand held camera work, but it works well in its style and you never feel you're missing anything. The directors, writers and actors who all worked together have done an outstanding job in making some good fun lighthearted entertainment. Not really one for the younger kids and the teens won't really get all the hidden jokes throughout but I think mums and dads who have a slightly warped sense of humour will love it.

When you think of New Zealand there are certain things that spring to mind, unfortunately most of those things now tend revolve around Hobbits. Despite New Zealand being used as the backdrop for Tolkien's fantasy world its still not really the first place you'd associate with vampires, especially vampires living in the suburbs of Wellington. So it was admittedly kinda surprising to see a vampire movie emerge from the island of Kiwis, but not just a vampire movie...a vampire comedy mockumentary.Put basically this film takes the popular reality TV concept and blends it with the popular slightly romantic vision of vampires (Anne Rice type vampires) whilst also adding other ghouls and mythical creatures in a bare bones hyperbole of blood. A camera crew stays in a decrepit house with four vampires and follows their daily routines trying to exist in the present day. The film crew have been given special permission to film these ancient creatures of the night as they prepare for a special event, a special ball...the crew were also given assurance they wouldn't be eaten.The four vampires are a mixed bunch from the distant pages of time. Viago (379 years old) is the main vampire who talks to us most of the time, he was an 18th century dandy, a wealthy man who is prim proper and pedantic and likes the house clean and tidy (the Lestat de Lioncourt of the bunch). Deacon is the bad boy of the group...or so he likes to think (183 years old). He's the young rebellious rock n roll leather pant wearing vampire who thinks he's hot stuff, the irony being he clearly isn't. 'If you were a Nazi after the war...uh-uh''If you were a vampire'...*shakes head*'If you were a Nazi vampire! no way!! I was outta there!'Vladislav is the second eldest vampire (862 years old) who grew up during the medieval ages and was a tyrant. He's the most dated and out of touch vampire, HE is the sexual deviant of the bunch, the ladies man. His appearance is more in line with the traditional romantic vampiric appearance (the Gary Oldman/Coppola vampire of the bunch). Then lastly there is Petyr who is the eldest vampire at 8000 years of age. This guy is obviously a homage to the Count Orlok character in the F.W. Murnau film 'Nosferatu'. He doesn't say anything but merely nods or hisses and is virtually more animalistic or creature-like than the others.So apart from the usual vampire-esque things you'd expect to see what is different about this movie? Well for one its all filmed with hand held cameras because its a reality show, not exactly a new idea but it makes the whole film look very realistic in terms of a reality show that is. They have clearly gone out and about in Wellington and filmed on the fly with real unknowing people which makes things more intriguing and fun. In fact its hard to tell at times if the people we see are in the movie or simply real folk unaware they are being filmed.Some of the main things that really stand out are the extremely humorous little chats the vamps have with the cam crew (ala Big Brother) as they bicker about each other and whine about life in general. It is absolutely hilarious to watch these guys moan and take the piss out of traditional vampire lore turning it into annoying everyday situations. A really clever aspect is the fact vampires don't cast a reflection...so how do they know what they look like? This is clever simply because you've probably never even thought about that. Vampires tend to look very glamorous in certain movies yet how do they know they look glamorous, they might look like shit. So we are presented with a brilliantly funny sequence where these vamps must draw each other in certain attire and make dummies to put the clothes on, so they have an idea of how they will look when they cruise the town at night.'I think we drink virgin blood because...it sounds cool''I think of it like this...if you're going to eat a sandwich...you would just enjoy it more if you knew no one had fucked it'Then there is the issue of how to kill and drain a victim without making a mess on the carpet and furniture. How do they get all their clothes cleaned, washing up all the blood stained cutlery and dishes, how to find victims/virgins, keeping their vampire skills honed, general entertainment, coping with modern technology, flying through windows, trying to hypnotise victims when they're glued to the TV or a laptop and getting to grips with a new vampire and his human friend. The answer to many of these things being a female human slave who acts like a personal secretary with a shopping list of victims which is a fantastic twist. You wouldn't think a film like this would have many special effects and if they did they'd be crappy, but you'd be wrong. OK there aren't lots of effects everywhere, they are sparse, but what we do see is cleverly done and highly effective in a tacky kind of way. We see the vamps flying around and hovering, Viago rises from his bed in that classic vertical manner, the guys change into bats, there are of course classic practical blood effects and most impressively we see the guys able to walk (and fight) up the walls and across the ceiling. One scene in particular shows two of the guys fighting up the walls and across the ceiling in one shot and it really does look fab (a rotating set I'm guessing). I must also add that the sets are really atmospheric too, again clearly basic but they work so well.The only thing I didn't quite like about this movie was the adding of other creatures of the night such as werewolves and zombies especially. I guess the werewolves I can accept but the way they are presented and acted out by the cast just doesn't quite work as well I think. The vampires have a clear distinction between themselves, you can send up different variations of vampires and there is so much you can do. With the werewolves its not really the same, one werewolf doesn't really differ from another, the jokes tend to be childish toilet/animal gags and they don't have any kind of distinctive look, they just look like regular boring humans. Of course once they turn things get a bit more exciting but then you lose the comedy aspect and it obviously becomes more of a genuine horror which you don't really want here. As for other monsters such as zombies that was a step too far for me, that felt like they were pushing it too much. I loved the cast in this film I really did, each of the three main vampires are really well portrayed and highly amusing throughout. In fact I can't even say which vampire was my favourite because they were all tops. Each actor had some very funny dialog and they are all gifted with amusing rubbery faces which helps. I won't lie and say its a perfect film that is full of laugh out loud moments from start to finish...but its damn close. Considering this came out of nowhere, the cast is unknown (to me), its a New Zealand made film (no disrespect) and the budget appears to be small...its a fine comedy that deserves much kudos. Its like...'Spinal Tap' but with vampires.'When you get four vampires in a flat obviously there's going to be a lot of tension, there's tension in any flatting situation'
One of the best comedies I've seen this year. If you get a chance to see this then do! =)

Mockumentary of a group of vampires flatmating in downtown Wellington. 2000 year old is pretty creepy. 2 month old doesnt get the rules of being a vampire. Occasional run in with werewolves . Funny and quirky.

If Australia gave us the scariest movie of the year with the Babadook then New Zeeland have provided us with the funniest move of the year.Drawing together the creators of the brilliant Flight of the Conchords and starring two of the original cast this mok-doc is hilarious and definitely stands up to repeat viewing. The nods to previous vampire films will please fans of the genre as well as fans of horror comedies such as The Evil Dead and Cabin in the Woods.This didn't get much advertisement upon release so I suggest you find a screening or buy it on DVD as I guarantee it will become a cult classic.
Was so good, but it got a bit boring at the very end.
"What we do in the Shadows" has little in way of plot but a whole lot of humour thanks to its mockumentary style. Deadpan comedy and hilarity make for a great movie.
Funny and charming, in its own quirky way, but even at 80 or so minutes it's a little stretched.
Pretty hilarious all-around... recommend it!
Possibly the funniest film I have seen all year possibly the best film i have seen this film over all perhaps even the best of the year overall.
My favourite comedy of the year.

This absurdly funny and very self-conscious/postmodern vampire mockumentary cross-breeds Dracula movies with MTV's The Real World. Set in New Zealand so they have Kiwi-filtered mock Eastern European accents, the result is exactly as you imagined and funnier than it ought to have any right to be. The reason it works is largely due to a witty script with a decent gag quota which takes rules and conventions in the vampire movie genre like they cannot see their reflections in the mirror, or that they can not come in unless they are asked and push them to their logical and surreal conclusions. The writers, well aware that the film can easily drift into a one-joke film stretched out too thin, have kept it sweet and under 90mins. The vampire comedy is hardly a tough category to compete in (as anyone who's even heard of Lesbian Vampire Killers or Dead And Loving It will attest) but we have finally found one where they managed to successfully fused horror with comedy on screen in an unforced and more than dignified manner.
Mildly amusing mockumentary about vampires set in New Zealand. Worth a few titters here and there so worth a watch.
Had no idea what this was. It's a brilliant comedy.

Short but sweet mockumentary about vampires just doing their thing, trying to live a modern life. It was a silly funny easy watch, but also self aware and nods to other vampire shows. Truly is "the Spinal Tap of vampire films".
One of the funniest and best comedy's i have ever seen, instantly in my top movies and looking to become a cult classic!

So unbelievably funny and deadpan and authentically mockumentary where it needs to be - "Hi, I'm Stuart and I'm a software analyst". It only gets stronger the longer it goes on and even take the funny away and you have a very dynamic and fully featured pic. Absolutely go and see this.
Laugh out loud funny and the characters are all amazing.
This was an hilarious mockumentary spoof about a groups of vampires living together in Wellington New Zealand. Its a great deal of fun and very gory in parts. My favourite character was Stu.
Charmingly fresh take on both the mockumentary and vampire genres. Good script, priceless expressions. A fun little film!
Loved it! Really cheesy, NZ fun. It's always an adventure to see Jemaine Clement. Many great lines, including something like watch your language, we're werewolves, not swear wolves.

This original one-joke comedy is more impressive for its fantastic special effects than for its plot, which begins belly-achingly hilarious but then starts to slowly wear off as the novelty gives place to familiarity, proving that some ideas work better when made into short movies.

A cross between Spinal Tap and horrible reality TV shows, this is a very entertaining comedy where at times just when you think the joke may start to wear thin, it'll make you laugh thanks to a witty one liner or a funny situation. Definitely one that will get better with repeated viewings, especially with an audience or a group of friends.

Hilarious and beautifully New Zealanderian (is that a word?). Probably wears a little long in the tooth for what is essentially a brilliant sketch idea, otherwise, perfectly played and delivered by all involved. Pokes at the vampiric tropes of yesteryear and finishes on a sweet note. Fun stuff.
A genuinely funny mockumentary.

It may not have the most clever inspiration behind it, but in the very basic terms of "laughs per minute", "What We Do in the Shadows" is a brilliant example of comedy that is up there with the best.Four vampires - Viago, Vladislav, Deacon and Petyr - have forgone the creepy castle setting that the vampires normally go for, in exchange for sharing a small flat in Wellington, New Zealand. A documentary crew come in to examine the life of these creatures as they try to find virgin blood, antagonize a group of werewolves and train up newly created vampire Nick. A series of mishaps occur, leading to a series of hilarious situations.Writer/director team Taika Waititi and Jemaine Clement also star in this mockumentary comedy, alongside a local cast including Jonathan Brugh, Ben Fransham, Cori Gonzalez-Macuer, Stu Rutherford, Jackie Van Beek and Clement's "Flight of the Concords" co-star Rhys Darby. All were accomplished enough to bring forward brilliant comic timing.This timing, alongside the quality of writing, is the main reason this movie is so hilarious. Yes, some of the jokes do edge towards sillyness, but this sillyness is a step above the cliched Hollywood style of humour that gets churned out every few weeks.I don't want to elevate this film too highly too early, as I haven't done any rewatching yet, but I must say that very few films have made me laugh this consistently throughout the film. This alone puts this film up there with "Airplane!" and "Monty Python's Life of Brian" (though maybe a tiny rung below the latter).A very funny film that nearly everyone needs to see. Immediately. Lest you be subjected to the procession of shame.

Not as consistently funny as you want it to be (is anything these days?) but at it's best, it's very, very good, and despite the sheer implausibility of the world it presents, has you accepting it without question.

Looked fwd to this, but it was amusing rather than hilarious. Great concept - vampire group house in the suburbs, actors were good - but these things were not exploited to their potential. Middle of the road cinematography and production values. Too slow editing, when it needed to be snappy. The film is a bit lazy.

Four vampires share a flat and... oh, sorry, I've told you the only joke in the entire dreary film.This is a mocumentary which instantly lets itself down as the camera crew seem totally disinterested in the murders which occur regularly or the appallingly boring nature of the vampires.Genuinely one the least interesting films I can remember seeing.
A snorting lough out loud comedy that warrants a second visit just to make sure any bits weren't missed whilst my body was having convulsions of hysteria.

This looked like it had so much promise but turned out to fall way below the mark. There are occasional inspired moments but overall nothing really to sink one's teeth into. Felt like a high school amateur night. Actors did their best with what was a superficial script. The first act is the best but it quickly becomes lifeless and directionless. I suppose if you've been living for thousands of years life would become pretty boring. If your taste is not for over the top mockumentary then give this a miss. If you like silly then suck it and see.
i felt sorry for the undead and didn't find the story witty nor funny!

Been waiting to see this one. Margaret and David hated this; but it's hard to hate a movie about a group of vampires sharing a house in Wellington. That alone is worth more than they gave it. Funny, silly, and some great one-liners. Seriously, how could you not like that?
Sore jaw as have not laughed so hard at the movies for a long time. Classic humour, timeless story line, and a number of great quotable lines. Great film, seriously funny and superb satire!
Not as hilarious as I hoped, but still enjoyable.
I haven't laughed so load in a cinema since I was a kid! LOVED IT!
Extremely funny New Zealand humour. Vampire genre done right.

I felt really nostalgic when I saw Wellington, remembered what a cool City it is. It's a really silly film, from the beginning to the end. Couldn't stop laughing at the silliness of it but it's not Hollywood clich� American humour at all. You can't predict what is about to happen and the jokes don't feel like 'one liners', they feel like they are connected perfectly the joke before that and the joke before that one.

Mags and David hated it, but I don't suppose they are great fans of Clement's other stuff. The style of humour is very much in the same vein as Flight of The Conchords, shit Rhys Darby basically plays a hairier version of Murray. It's not as complete a film as Waititi's last flick 'Boy', but it's funny so it gets a pass.

What you get is one of the better comedies or the year and a damn good horror comedy that manages to set itself apart from movies like Shaun of the Dead, Slither and Zombieland. With its mockumentary execution What We Do in the Shadows is able to make fun of the genre but embrace the characters, throwing plot to the side but exhibiting great satire and also a lot of heart. This is guided but good direction and also by the fact that the film is played straight and not like the characters are in on the joke (though the actors are of course).

Just saw this tonight. Everything everyone's been saying is true. Think Underworld meets Spinal Tap meets Napoleon Dymanite. It's awkward, it's inventive, it's HILARIOUS. Simple infectious humour has created a timeless quotable classic creating a fresh new look on a tired genre you probably never thought possible. Pure genius. Do yourself a favour and go see this film IMMEDIATELY. Movies that nail their goals this perfectly don't come along too often and you'll want to be there just to be able to say "I saw this in cinemas" when this movie becomes the stuff of legend. Look out for the little girls on the hunt for a pedophile, and find out why vampires prefer the blood of virgins. Well would you rather eat a sandwich that's been fucked?
Very funny movie that I is very well done.
Very original and funny. There are plenty of laugh out loud moments to be had. My highlight being the werewolves lead by Rhys Darby.
The whole concept just works.Its basic the trailer extended to an hour and 20 minutes.
This has got to be my second favorite film of all time, great laughs and just a all around good time.

It's another great, offbeat New Zealand comedy, with constant and clever laughs delivered by a consistently hilarious cast - one that makes it feel like New Zealand comedy really does stand out from everyone else's.(Excellent)
One of the best movies I have seen as of late. The humour kept rolling throughout the film. Each character was well developed and an absolute laugh riot.
I haven't laughed that much in a movie in ages, this is an instant classic comedy, a MUST see!
Brilliant understated comedy.

low-key, witty fun on horrors of flatting and trying to fit into a square world when you are a round peg (so to speak). Full of in-jokes only Wellingtonians will get (e.g. the zombies live in Karori...) but they don't spoil the fun.

This was a total surprise, and a wonderful one at that. Every gag appears and then has its twist and clever visual or off focus support. Very clever film making as well as comedy. For those of us who love Wellington, i can tell all others that there are a host of 'in jokes' in the locations chosen, the placement of events and the people who just appear in windows and cut away shots. A very clever and funny link to a wonderful city. Just go and laugh your heart out, but be careful who you are sitting next to!!!

Fantastic! The "Mockumentary" format was unobtrusive and fit the story line well. It was hilarious, a lot of puns and if you like awkward humour this is one for you. It had a strange way of making fun of itself the whole time. It is a bit short and it's not epic or revolutionary, you won't walk out shocked or awed, however you will leave smiling, laughing and chatting about "that bit where..." This is a must see.
How can we watch it in the US? Netfix, Hulu, or Amazon? Who will be the smart one to pick it up?

Hate to brag, but I've seen it! Not only is it funny, clever, insightful, and got some pretty impressive special effects, but it's actually deserving of the hype. I could be called biased as a New Zealand native, but I've never been a huge fan of Flight of the Conchords, and didn't like Eagle Vs Shark, so we can put patriotism aside. I liked this film as a film buff, and the marketing campaign was genius - miss at your peril, because this one's going to get a lot of mileage!
Quintessential New Zealand humor with enough bite and endurance to appeal to the international crowd. As funny as it is silly. And as silly as it is cleverly crafted.

This is probably the most genuinely funny and competently-made Kiwi film I've seen in a very long time. The dynamic coupling of Taika and Jemaine is the NZ deadpan equivalent of someone like Lord and Miller, only with a hell of a lot more absurdity. As with L&M, it's more than just sight gags. There's actual wit permeating the dialogue and everything that happens is in benefit to the genre or characters, respectively.I'll wait for How to Train your Dragon 2 and Interstellar before making any ludicrous claims, but from how great WWDITS is, it has severe clout in the 'best of year' category for me.
Smart and breathing fresh life into such an overdone genre, What We Do In The Shadows is quite possibly the best comedy to come out of New Zealand so far!
